intro: Camissonia cheiranthifolia, commonly known as the fringed poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its delicate, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink and purple. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. It typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is often found in coastal areas. Camissonia cheiranthifolia is a member of the Papaveraceae family, which includes other poppies and related species.
